newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Feb 4.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Feb 4.

text.p: The New York Times reported the following business stories on Tuesday:
* Kmart Corp and Waban Inc are negotiating a deal to form the nation's third-largest home improvement chain by combining Kmart's Builder Square stores and Waban's Homebase chain.
* Mercury Finance hired an outside corporate turnaround specialist, William Brandt, to help it avoid bankruptcy.

* Foreign auto makers made large gains in the American auto market in January, reporting combined sales that rose 10.9 percent, while combined sales of U.S. auto giants Chrysler and General Motors dropped a tenth of one percent.

* Reports from the Commerce Department, which said construction spending fell and personal incomes outpaced spending in December, and data showing a January slowdown in manufacturing, could mean the Fed will not feel compelled to raise interest rates when it meets this week.
* Signs of slower growth gave a boost to the Treasury market, where the yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.73 percent.
* AT&T Chief Financial Officer Richard Miller resigned unexpectedly.
* Guan Jinsheng, the central figure in a scandal involving Shanghai's leading securities firm, was sentenced to 17 years in prison.

* PepsiCo's Taco Bell said it would put up the creative part of its advertising account for review. That part of the account is now handled by Bozell Worldwide and has billings estimated at $200 million.
* Financier Carl Icahn named his investment advisors in preparation for a proxy assault on RJR Nabisco's food business.
* The future of Venezuelan airline Viasa depends on how its employees vote on a $55 million plan by the Venezuelan government and Spain's Iberia Air Lines to rescue it from bankruptcy.
* A company owned 80 percent by America Online has bought WP Studio, the producer of an online guide to New York City.
* Computer Associates Chairman Charles Wang's competitiveness and adaptability serves him well both in the board room and on the basketball court.
* A deepening trade deficit, a weakening currency and soaring wages indicate that economic growth could be slowing in South Korea, the world's 11th-largest economy.
